texts.en: Reham is an 18-year-old married young woman with no children yet. Her husband is employed and gets a low salary, which is not enough to cover all costs. Reham is requesting a 1,500 USD youth loan from FATEN to help her cover the cost of purchasing new living room furniture and installing new curtains in order to improve the living conditions in her house. Taking this loan will offer to Reham and her husband comfortable furniture so they can enjoy living in their house. Reham appears in the photo.

loans.use: to purchase new living room furniture and install new curtains.

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah is requesting another loan. Her previous loan enabled her improve her retail shop business and take her children to school with the additional income. 

For this reason Leah is coming for another loan to expand her shop by purchasing bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, beans and cooking fat oil. This will enable her to generate more income so as to diversify her business to real estate in the near future.

loans.use: purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, beans and cooking fat oil.

loans.name: Raya

texts.en: Raya is taking out another Kiva loan of Ksh 50,000. With the new loan, Raya plans to use it for personal reasons. She plans to purchase water pipes and install piped water in her home. She is grateful for Kiva loans, as she has been able to provide food for her family.

loans.use: To purchase water pipes and install piped water in her home

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en: Saumu is taking out another Kiva loan of Kes 40,000 to expand on her existing business. With the loan, she wants to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, and rice. She is grateful for Kiva lenders and Yehu microfinance for the opportunity.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, maize flour, and rice

loans.name: Aleles Group

texts.en:
Nicholas is a member of Aleles Group in Teso District. He is pictured with 11 One Acre Fund farmers, seven women and four men. Nicholas is standing on the right with his hand raised. He is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of sweet potato, millet, and sorghum cultivation. Nicholas is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. He joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and to use increased profits to send his children to school.

Nicholas thought his harvest last year was poor. He hopes that as a One Acre Fund farmer he can have an excellent harvest. He plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to send his children to school and perhaps save for the future. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Nicholas’ group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 5.5 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potatoes, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Floribelia

texts.es:
Floribelia, solicita un nuevo préstamo, por la necesidad de obtener un mejor financiamiento y este le permitirá comprar más materia prima como lo es: tela, zippers, hilos, botones y también para el mantenimiento de las maquinas. 
Con el crédito anterior  le ayudo a comprar insumos para el negocio y darle mantenimiento a  las maquinas, aumento el trabajo y este no se acumuló, al igual se obtuvieron los ingresos deseados.
Las condiciones del hogar y económicas se mantienen estables, hay un nuevo ser que esta por nacer.
texts.en:
Floribelia is requesting a new loan because she needs to obtain a better funding. This will allow her to buy more raw materials such as fabric, zippers, thread, and buttons and also to maintain her machines. 

Her previous loan helped her buy supplies for her business and maintain her machines. Her workload increased and she was able to keep up while also earning the income she wanted. 

Her home and financial situation have remained stable and there is a new child on the way.

loans.use: purchase raw materials such as fabric, zippers, thread and buttons as well as maintain her machines.

loans.name: Victor Manuel

texts.es:
Víctor, requiere de un nuevo préstamo, por la necesidad  de reparar una máquina, ya que algunas partes de ella se han dañado.
Con el crédito anterior le ayudo a mejora su productividad y para comprar material para mantenimiento de sus máquinas. Las condiciones familiares han cambiado ya que le ha permitido darle una  mejor educación a sus hijos e ingresos económicos para el hogar.
texts.en:
Victor needs a new loan so that he can repair one of his sewing machines since some of the parts are broken.

His previous loan helped him increase his productivity and buy materials for the maintenance of his machines. His family situation has changed since he has been able to give his children a better education and earn more for his household.

loans.use: to pay for repairs on his sewing machine.

loans.name: Roset's Group

texts.en:
Roset's Group is comprised of three hardworking women. Rose is 23 years old and lives in the town of Hima in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has one child who is currently in school. For the past three years, Rose has been working hard to manage her small business which sells goats.

To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 1,900,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more goats and will help Rose generate greater profits and pay tuition for her child. Rose hopes that, in the future, she will be able to grow the business. 
 
Rose is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more goats to resell.

loans.name: Beatha

texts.en: Beatha is 38 years old. She sells electronics and has been in the business for five years. She wants to use the loan to buy more radios, TV sets and irons for clothes. The profits from the business will be used to renovate the house. Her business has been making a great change to her family's life, and this can be attributed to the previous loan.

loans.use: to buy TV sets, radios and irons for resale.

loans.name: Nasimbo Group

texts.en:
Nasimbo is a group of 13 farmers in the Chwele District represented by Maximilla. The group has 9 women and 4 men. Maximilla is on the right of the photo with her hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to her on credit consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ an acre of sweet potato, millet and sorghum. Maximilla joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season. Maximilla joined One Acre Fund so that she can grow enough food for the family and use her increased profits to send her children to school.

Maximilla described her harvest as very good last year, but believes she can have an even better one this year. She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send her children to school and save for the future. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Maximilla’s group will receive 6.5 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potato, millet, and sorghum

loans.name: Ligaya

texts.en:
Ligaya is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a dry goods business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 18,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase more dry goods to resell for her dry goods business. Ligaya successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

NWTF is re-listing Ligaya's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more dry goods to resell in stall.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a married woman, aged 52 years. She owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Rehema operates a charcoal-selling business where she sells from her home to her neighbours and villagers. Her greatest monthly challenge is the high-cost of transportation. For the Kshs 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase charcoal to sell.  She dreams of expanding into a wholesale shop in the future.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is a married woman, aged 30 years. She has three children, two of whom attend school. Victoria owns a house that has no electricity or piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Victoria operates a vegetable stall, selling from her home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces stiff competition from other vegetable operators in her business.
 
With the Kshs 20,000 loan she wants to purchase sacks of tomatoes, potatoes, fruits and green vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of tomatoes, potatoes, fruits and green vegetables to sell

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
As a married mother of four children, Lucia works hard to support her family.

She has a furniture-making business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending. Lucia is borrowing 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy materials like wood, paint, brushes, nails, etc., for her furniture-making business.

Lucia has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy materials like wood, paint, brushes, nails, etc., for her furniture-making business.

loans.name: Bashir

texts.en:
Bashir is a hardworking man, aged 50 years. He is happily married with five children. He grew up in a very humble family that had few assets and no ability to pay school fees to educate him. He opted to work in the nearby national park as a gardener to earn a living. Due to his hard work, he managed to save some money and bought a piece of land in Rwabarata, where he planted a banana plantation. This enabled him to get a living to the extent that he even managed to get a wife, who is also hardworking and developmental. 

His farming project had been growing until last year, when it was affected by banana wilt and drought. He is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings to buy insecticides and manure to upgrade his banana plantation. He hopes with the insecticides, his quality of plantains will improve and so will his income.

loans.use: To buy manure and insecticides.

loans.name: Furaha Group

texts.en:
Furaha is a group of 16 farmers in Teso District represented by Margaret. The group has 10 women and six men.  Margaret is on the right of the photo with her hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to her on credit consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of sweet potatoes, millet and sorghum. Margaret first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Margaret joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and to use increased profits to send her children to school.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Margaret was only able to harvest two bags of maize per ½ acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, she was able to harvest six bags per ½ acre. She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send her children to school and perhaps to buy a cow. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Margaret’s group will receive 8 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potatoes, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Nigogo

texts.en: Nigogo is taking out another Kiva loan of 15,000 KES (Kenyan shillings) to boost her retail shop business. With the 15,000 KES, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, sugar, cooking fat oil and maize flour for resale. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing another business in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, sugar, cooking fat oil and maize flour for resale.

loans.name: United Family Group

texts.en:
United Family is a group of 16 farmers in Chwele District represented by Thomas. The group has 11 women and five men. Thomas is on the right of the photo with his hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to him on credit consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of sweet potatoes, millet and sorghum. Thomas joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season. Thomas joined One Acre Fund so that he could gain access to best input prices of hybrid seeds and fertilizer.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Thomas was only able to harvest four bags of maize per ½ acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, he was able to harvest five bags per ½ acre. He plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to send his children to school and to buy cattle. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Thomas’ group will receive 8 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potato, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a 52-year-old married man. He has two children with ages between two and six years. He describes himself as an honest and focused man. 

Stephen operates a butcher shop where he sells meat. He has been involved in this business for five years. His business is located in a profitable business environment and his primary customers are local residents. He describes his biggest business challenge as insufficient funds for improving the business. He will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy meat to sell. 

His goal is to expand his business within five years. This is his second loan with SMEP DTM after managing to pay a loan of KES 20,000 successfully.

loans.use: to buy meat to sell

loans.name: Zidisha Group

texts.en:
Mary is a member of Zidisha Group in Chwele District. She is pictured with 17 One Acre Fund farmers, 11 women and six men. She is receiving a loan for ½ acre of sweet potato, millet, and sorghum cultivation. Mary first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access the best input prices and grow enough food for her family.

Mary described her harvest as good last year, but believes she can have an even better one this year. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school and save for the future. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½  acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Mary’s group will receive 8.5 acres worth of inputs on credit. Mary is standing on the right with her hand raised.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potatoes, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Sinani Group

texts.en:
Sinani Group is located in Chwele District. It is a group of six women and three men led by Phillip, who is pictured on the right with his hand raised. He is receiving an input loan for half an acre of sweet potato, millet and sorghum cultivation. Phillip first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2011 Long Rains season and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Phillip joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and use increased profits to send his children to school.

Phillip described his harvest as very good last year, but he believes he can have an even better one this year. He plans on using future profits from the harvest to repair his home and buy cattle. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive half an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Phillip’s group will receive 4.5 acres worth of inputs on credit.

The field officer is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potato, millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Ageun Group

texts.en:
Joseph’s group has 16 farmers and is located in Teso District. Joseph is pictured on the right of Ageun Group with his hand raised. Joseph is pictured amongst the seven men and nine women of his group. He will receive input loans capable of planting ½ an acre with sorghum, millet, and Sweet Potato. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Joseph’s first season with One Acre Fund. He joined this year in order to gain access to best input prices of hybrid seeds and fertilizer and to improve his living standards.

Joseph thought his harvest last year was poor. He hopes that as a One Acre Fund farmer he can have an excellent harvest. He plans on using future profits from the harvest to send his children to school and to repair his home. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Joseph’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 8 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potatoes, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
This is 28-year-old Margaret from Torkpoi town in Bo. She is married with two children between the ages of 8 and 11. She got married at an early age, and she did not go to school so her mother could train her in business.

Margaret runs a table business within a busy market area; she sells palm oil, maggie, onions, pepper and salt. She has been running this business for 5 years. She works at her business every day.  She says that the main challenge to her business is sometimes her business is very slow, and she has insufficient capital to improve herself.

Margaret has requested a loan in order to buy different kinds of food like palm oil, maggie, onions, pepper and salt.  The extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business. In the future, she plans to expand her business to a shop level. She appreciates your support.

loans.use: To buy different kinds of food like palm oil, maggie, onions, pepper and salt

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu operates a retail shop business. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation. She dreams of expanding her business to be a wholesale supplier of firewood in the village. 

With the 30,000 Kenyan shillings she wants to purchase wheat flour, rice, sugar and cooking fat oil. She decided to join to Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, rice, sugar and cooking fat oil.

loans.name: Nuru Group

texts.en:
Pauline is pictured on the right with her hand raised amongst her Nuru Group members. The 16 of them, 10 women and six men, are farmers in Chwele District. Farming inputs will be delivered to her on credit consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of sweet potatoes, millet, and sorghum. Pauline joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season. Pauline joined One Acre Fund so that she could access the best input prices and use increased profits to send her children to school.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Pauline was only able to harvest two bags of maize per ½ acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, she was able to harvest eight bags per ½ acre. She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send her children to school and save for the future. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Pauline’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on eight acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potatoes, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan operates a tailoring business, making women's and men's suits to sell at home. She cites seasonality and stiff competition from other tailoring operators to be her major challenges. 

With the Kshs 20,000 loan she wants to purchase clothing materials and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase clothing materials and sewing thread for her business

loans.name: Wenecorde

texts.en:
Wenecorde is married and works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a loan of PHP 20,000 through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell like shampoo, noodles, snack foods, etc.

Wenecorde has been in this business for 11 years and has previously received funds through Kiva.

Wenecorde aspires to save money to expand her business and repair her family home.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell like shampoo, noodles, snack foods, etc. in her general store.

loans.name: Leonor

texts.es: La Sra. Leonor es una mujer de 67 años,  es madre y abuela. A pesar de que ella esta pensionada desde hace ya varios años sigue superándose vendiendo ropa usada, ya que comenta que se puede valer por si mima todavía y que no quiere ser una carga para sus hijos. Ella necesita de nuestra ayuda para poder mejorar su baño ya que comenta que quiere evitar alguna fuga en las tuberías internas. La Sra. Leonor quiere que su vivienda siempre este impecable para cuando sus hijos y nietos vayan a visitarla.
texts.en:
Mrs. Leonor , 67, is a mother and grandmother. Although she retired several years ago, she is still successfully selling used clothing to earn a living. She says that she wants to fend for herself so that she is not a burden on her children. 

Leonor requires assistance from Kiva as she needs to fix up her bathroom, and wants to avoid leakages in the internal plumbing. Leonor wants her home to always be in great condition for when her children and grandchildren visit.

loans.use: to fix the internal plumbing in her bathroom

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Meet 50-year-old Margaret from Torkpoi town in Bo. She is married with two children between the ages of 30 and 37. She started her business because she did not go to school. Before she was a gardener. Margaret established her fish business because she wanted to create income to support her business. She works at the business every day for eight hours a day. She describes her major problem poor transportation vehicles and road network.

Margaret requires a loan in order to buy more dried fish, palm oil and native rice. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and start a savings account. In the future, she plans to expand her business to an even higher level. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more dried fish, palm oil and native rice.

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en:
Meet 47-year-old Mariama from Torkpoi town in Bo. She is married with five children between the ages of 8 and 27 years. Three of her children are currently attending school. In 1989, Mariama established her palm oil business. She began her business because she needed a source of income to support herself. She works at the business eight hours a day and six days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is the poor road network within her area of operation.

Mariama requires a loan in order to buy local foodstuffs like gari and palm oil. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to have a permanent business location and improve her family's welfare. In the future, Mariama plans to open a palm oil store. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy local foodstuffs like gari and palm oil.

loans.name: Francisco Antonio

texts.es:
Francisco, solicita un nuevo préstamo para seguir invirtiendo en el cultivo. Este le permitirá comprar insumos agrícola tales como: abonos, herbicidas, insecticidas, plaguicidas y para preparar la tierra.
El crédito anterior le permitió aumentar la producción. Las condiciones han mejorado en el hogar y en el cultivo.
texts.en:
Francisco is asking for a new loan in order to continue investing in cultivation. This will allow him to buy agricultural supplies such as: fertilizers, herbicides, insecticides, and pesticides, as well as to prepare the soil.

His previous loan allowed him to increase production. The conditions in his home and in his cultivation have improved.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies such as: fertilizers, herbicides, insecticides, and pesticides.

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a videoke rental business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 10,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy an additional unit for her videoke rentals business.

Marivic has been in this business for three years. Marivic earns more income from a general store.

Marivic has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy an additional unit for her videoke rentals business.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is 45 years old and married with 7 children, ages 5 to 26. She runs a wood business in Torkpoi town in Bo. Two of her children are currently attending school. 

She's been in this business for the past 10 years and sells wood and palm oil.  She says that at present her business is doing well. She started her business to fund her children's education.

She requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to buy more palm oil and wood. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her improve her life and her family's well-being. In the future, she would like to expand her business more. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy more palm oil and wood

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy welding bars and a compressor machine.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
Mercedes, solicita un nuevo préstamo porque necesita más capital de trabajo y por la buena atención que la institución le brinda. Este le ayudara para comprar carnes, arroz, frijol, aceite, entre otros para la venta de comida. 
Con el crédito anterior le ayudo a fortalecer el negocio y con las ganancias ha logrado cubrir los gastos. Las condiciones familiares se mantienen estables.
texts.en:
Mercedes is requesting a new loan because she needs more working capital as well as the attention the institution offers her. This loan will help her to buy meat, rice, beans, oil, and other ingredients for the food she sells.

Her previous loan helped her to strengthen her business and she was able to cover all of her expenses. Her family's situation has remained stable.

loans.use: to buy meat, rice, beans, oil, and other ingredients.

loans.name: Marcos Humberto

texts.es:
Marcos, solicita un nuevo préstamo porque requiere invertir más en la productividad. Este le permitirá comprar insumos agrícolas como lo es: abono, herbicidas, insecticidas, plaguicidas entre otros y semilla para el cultivo.
Con el crédito anterior aumentaron sus ingresos y lo invirtió en la compra de productos básicos para el hogar. Las condiciones familiares son estables y poseen buena salud, la situación económica  mejoro.
texts.en:
Marcos is requesting a new loan because he needs to invest more in his business to increase productivity. This loan will enable him to purchase agricultural supplies such as fertilizer, herbicides, insecticides and pesticides, including seeds for cultivation.

With his previous loan, Marcos increased his revenues and invested in the purchase of basic household products. His family is stable and in good health, and his economic situation has improved.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural supplies such as fertilizer, herbicides, and insecticides

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza is 33 years old and married with four children who are all in school. Analiza works very hard to provide for them.

Analiza runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 19,500 loan through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell.

Analiza has been in this business for 13 years and sells a variety of items such as soap, snack foods, noodles and other groceries. 

In the future Analiza would like to save enough money to build a restaurant at the public market.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
As a married parent of 5 children, Elisa works hard to support her family.

She has a copra business in the Philippines, and she also earns additional income from raising pigs and selling clothing. Elisa is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF to buy more coconut for her copra business.

Elisa has been sustaining her business activities through her past 13 loans from NWTF, and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough to provide a financial security for her family.

loans.use: To buy more coconut for her copra business

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is 45 years old and married with two children, aged 11 and 16 years. She runs a clothing business in Torkpoi town in Sierra Leone. Her children are currently attending school and her husband is a driver, but his income is not enough to support the home. So she went into the petty trading business.

Fatmata sells gari and clothing within her surrounding area.  She describes her major problem as the low purchasing power of customers. 

She requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more clothing material and gari.  She says that the extra income from this loan will help her improve the life of herself and her family. In the future, she would like to open a big clothing store. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more clothing material and gari.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina is 58 years old and married with two children. Josefina works very hard to provide for them.

Josefina runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell in her store.

Josefina has been in this business for ten years and sells a variety of items such as snack foods, soap, detergent and other miscellaneous items. 

In the future, Josefina would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell in her store

loans.name: Zone Mini Group

texts.en:
Tutut is 47 years old and from Kebon Pala, in the east of Jakarta. She is married, but does not yet have a child. 

Tutut has been the owner of a small household needs store for more than three years. Her business is in front of her house. As time goes by, she increases her kinds of merchandise one by one. From this business, she pays medical fees for her mom, who suffered a stroke.  

Tutut will use this loan to buy rice, a gas holder, and an etalase (window display).  

In the future, Tutut has a dream to have a big grocery store and stationery store. In her environment, she has many competitors, but she enjoys running this business because she also has many customers.

loans.use: to buy some sacks of rice, a gas holder, and an etalase (window display).

loans.name: Nihad

texts.en:
Nihad lives in Kilifi area of Coast Province, Kenya. She is married and has two school-going children. She owns a retail shop, a business which has been running for six years. In the business, Nihad sells mattresses, bed sheets, and related items. She also runs a salon.

Nihad learned about Milango through friends who invited her to the group. She joined with the aim of accessing credit to improve her business operations. Her main challenge is occasional low demand. 

Nihad is applying for a loan of 31,500 Kenyan shillings to buy more mattresses. The extra income from the loan will be added to her savings to improve on the living standard of her family and to restock the shop.

loans.use: To buy more mattresses.

loans.name: Marigold

texts.en:
Marigold is 58 years old and married with 3 children. Marigold works very hard to provide for them.

Marigold runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more grocery products to sell in her store.

Marigold has been in this business for five years and sells a variety of items such as bread, soft drinks, biscuits and other groceries. 

In the future Marigold would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products to sell in her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy grocery stock such as maize, beans, rice and cooking fat.

loans.name: Olinda

texts.es:
Olinda, solicita un nuevo préstamo por la necesidad de adquirir más mercadería para seguir su negocio de venta de medicina natural. Este le permitirá comprar medicina tales como: rábano yodado, hígado crudo, complejo B, entre otros.
Con el crédito anterior aumento la clientela y tiene mejores ingresos, estos los invierte en los gastos del hogar. Las condiciones económicas han mejorado, se mantiene el mismo grupo familiar y gozan de buena salud.
texts.en:
Olinda is requesting a new loan because she needs to acquire more merchandise to continue her business selling natural medicines. This loan will let her buy medicines such as iodized radish, raw liver, vitamin B-complex, and others.

Her previous loan helped her to attract more customers and increase her earnings, which she was able to invest in her household expenses. Her financial situation has improved and she is able to provide for her family, who are in good health.

loans.use: to buy medicines, iodized radish, raw liver, vitamin B-complex, and others.

loans.name: Marina Abigail

texts.es:
Marina, se dedica a la crianza de ganado y cerdos.  Ella vive actualmente con su esposo, sus dos hijos de edades 13 y 14 años, ambos estudian y dependen de ella.  Esta ocupacion la heredo de sus padres  y hoy lo realiza con su compañero de vida; la ventaja que el terreno con pasto que posee es propio, para así mantener el ganado y desde hace 22 años lo realiza.
El préstamo que requiere lo invertirá en la compra de ganado de repasto debido a que por el momento tiene suficiente sácate picado para el mantenimiento. Este le permitirá retener el ganado e incrementarlo. Los riesgos más vulnerables sobre este negocio son los cambios repentinos de los precios del ganado  y una posible enfermedad que afecte. 
Su objetivo es obtener más ganancias para crear un negocio más amplio, que le permita generar más ingresos económicos y así mejorar las condiciones de vida la familia.
texts.en:
Marina raises cattle and pigs. She lives with her husband and her two children, who are 13 and 14 years old. Both are studying and depend on her. She inherited this occupation from her parents and now works at it with her life companion. She has the advantage that she owns her own pasture land, which she uses to sustain her cattle; she has been doing this for 22 years.

She will invest the loan that she needs in the purchase of cattle for fattening, because at the moment she has enough hay to maintain them. This will allow her to feed her herd and grow it. The risks to which she is most vulnerable in this business are sudden changes in the price of cattle, and also possible diseases that could affect her herd.

Her goal is to earn more so that she can grow her business. This will allow her to generate more income and improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: to buy cattle for fattening.

loans.name: Anjelica

texts.en: Anjelica is a married woman. She has one child. She describes herself to be customer friendly. She operates a retail store where she sells flour, sugar, salt and rice. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located at a favorable business area, and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be high transportation costs. She will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy home products to sell. Her business goal is to expand her business within five years. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy more home products for selling.

loans.name: Ady Claribel

texts.es:
Ady, requiere de un nuevo préstamo por la necesidad de cultivar maíz y por la buena atención que el personal de la institución le brinda. Este le ayudara para el pago de dos manzanas de tierra para llevar acabo el cultivo.
Con el crédito anterior aumento la producción y las ganancias obtenidas las invirtió en los gastos básicos del hogar.  Las condiciones económicas han mejorado y el grupo familiar se mantiene gracias a este crédito que obtuvo.
texts.en:
Ady needs another loan in order to grow corn as well as for the opportunity to work with the lending institution's staff. This loan will help Ady to pay for the land she needs to plant on. 

With her previous loan, she increased her production and invested her earnings in the basic household expenses.  Her financial situation has improved and she is able to help provide for her family, thanks to the loan she received.

loans.use: to buy two plots of land to plant on.

loans.name: Erika Lissette

texts.es:
Erika, solicita un nuevo préstamo por la necesidad de aumentar el inventario de su negocio. Este le permitirá comprar churros, sodas, dulces, galletas, maíz, queso, entre otros.
Con el crédito anterior aumentaron las ventas y mejoro el negocio porque la clientela incremento. Las condiciones económicas se optimizaron porque mejoro la casa y adquirió electrodomésticos.
texts.en:
Erika is requesting a new loan because she needs to increase the inventory in her business. This will allow her to buy chips, sodas, sweets, cookies, corn, and cheese, among other items.

With the previous loan she grew her sales and improved the business because her client base grew. Her economic conditions were improved; she improved her house and bought some appliances.

loans.use: to buy chips, sodas, sweets, cookies, corn, and cheese, among other items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy two calves to later sell.

loans.name: Maria De La Paz

texts.es:
María, tiene una tienda de productos básico para el hogar,  también se dedica a la crianza de cerdos y aves de corral. Ella es una persona aplicada en sus actividades de negocio, está acompañada y tiene cuatro hijos de edades de 4, 7, 10, 14 años ellos estudian; no tiene familiares en el extranjero.
El negocio lo realiza  en su casa desde la mañana  hasta por la tarde dependiendo de la demanda, esta actividad la inicio a raíz de la misma necesidad económica; la ventaja es que en el zona no tiene competencias. El préstamo que requiere lo invertirá en la compra de artículos de la canasta básica para ampliar dicho negocio, aceite, pastas, pan, galletas, gaseosas.
Esta inversión le ayudara a tener una tienda surtida, que le permita tener más posibilidades de incrementar sus ganancias. Su sueño es invertir más para tener un negocio grande y rentable que genera más ingresos económicos para aportar con el estudio a sus hijos  y así brindarles una mejor educación, alimentación y optimizar la calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
María has her own store where she sells staple home products, and she also raises pigs and poultry. She is dedicated to her work, and is married with four children ages 4, 7, 10, and 14 who are all studying in school. María has no relatives abroad.

María runs her store at home from morning to evening, depending on customer demand. She started her business to improve her income, and has an advantage that she does not have any competition in her neighborhood. María requires this loan to invest in basic food items to expand her stock, such as oil, pasta, bread, cookies, and sodas.

This investment will help María to keep her store well stocked, giving her more opportunities to increase her profits. Her dream is to invest more in order to build a large and profitable business that generates more income. She wants to contribute to her children's schooling and give them a better education, good nutrition and optimize the quality of life for her family.

loans.use: to purchase oil, pasta, bread, cookies and sodas

loans.name: Maria Angela

texts.es:
María, solicita un nuevo préstamo, porque los créditos es un buen recurso económico para crecer en el negocio de cerdos. Este le permitirá comprar dos cerdos, uno  para destazarlo y el otro para crecerlo; al mismo tiempo comprar concentrados.
Con el crédito anterior ha aumentado las ganancias en el negocio. Las condiciones familiares han mejorado, ya que por los ingresos que obtiene en el negocio aporta a su familia para la alimentación u otros y optimizar proyectos a futuro.
texts.en:
María is requesting a new loan because the loans are a good economic resource for growing her pig raising business. This will allow her to buy two pigs, one for butchering and the other for raising. She will also buy feed.

With the previous loan, she increased her earnings from the business. Her family’s living conditions have improved; with the income she earns from her business she contributes to her family for food and other things, and also helps with future projects.

loans.use: to buy two pigs and feed.

loans.name: Akibelo Kin Group

texts.en:
Akibelo Kin is a group of 11 farmers in the Teso District represented by John. The group has 5 women and 6 men. John is on the right of the photo with his hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to him on credit consisting of the necessary materials to plant a ½ acre of sweet potato, millet and sorghum. The 2013 Long Rains season will be John’s first season with One Acre Fund. He joined this year in order to gain access to the best input prices of hybrid seed and fertilizer.

John managed to harvest eight bags of maize on a ½ acre of land last year. As a One Acre Fund farmer, he hopes to harvest even more. He hopes that his profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send his children to school and repair his home. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. John’s group will receive 5.5 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potato, millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Maria Del Carmen

texts.es:
Maria, solicita un nuevo préstamo, por la necesidad de mejorar el negocio. Este le permitirá comprar diversidad de ropa para ampliar la venta: blusas, faldas, ropa interior.
El crédito anterior le permitió mantenerse en su negocio. Las condiciones familiares y económicas no han cambiado.
texts.en:
Maria is requesting another loan in order to improve her business. This loan will allow her to buy a variety of clothing to improve her sales: shirts, skirts, and underwear. 

Her previous loan helped her to maintain her business. Her financial and family's situation have not changed.

loans.use: to buy a variety of shirts, skirts, and underwear.

loans.name: Amado

texts.es:
Amado, solicita un nuevo préstamo, porque necesita solventar pedidos para la temporada, este  le servirá para  pago de mano de obra y elaboración de pitas de mezcal.
Con el crédito anterior le permitió salir adelante con la demanda que se presentó. El negocio le ha ayudado mucho para que sus hijos salgan adelante ya que están estudiando.
texts.en:
Amado is requesting a new loan because he needs to fulfill orders he has for the season. This will allow him to pay for labor and to make string from mescal fiber.

The previous loan allowed him to fulfill the customer demand that existed. The business has helped him a lot, so his children will get ahead because they’re studying.

loans.use: to pay for labor and to make string from mescal fiber.

loans.name: Fatima Margarita

texts.es:
Fátima, solicita un nuevo préstamo por necesidad de invertir más en el negocio y por el buen trato que el personal de la institución le brinda. Este le ayudara a comprar sandalias, zapatos, ropa para bebe, entre otros. 
Con el crédito anterior, obtuvo mejores ganancias y la clientela más satisfecha por cubrir sus necesidades. Las condiciones familiares han mejorado ya que los hijos están estudiando  y desea siempre ayudarles.
texts.en:
Fátima is requesting a new loan as she needs to increase investment in her business. She is grateful for the good treatment she receives from the institution staff. This loan will help her to purchase sandals, shoes, and baby clothes among other items.

With the previous loan, Fátima increased her profits and her customers are happy as she was able to satisfy their needs. Conditions have improved for her family, as her children are studying and she always wants to help them.

loans.use: to purchase sandals, shoes, and baby clothes, among other items.

loans.name: Martha Silvia

texts.es:
Martha tiene 37 años de edad. Esta acompañada y tiene un hija de ocho años de edad. Su compañero de vida es pescador artesanal y ella se encarga de administrar el negocio de su mamá situado a la orilla de la playa, debido a que su madre tiene diabetes y no puede continuar a cargo del negocio. Para iniciar, ella solicito un primer crédito para comprar una cocina y tres juegos de mesa, tiene un año de experiencia y le ha ido muy bien. Su compañero de vida le provee del pescado y ella se encarga de prepararlo y venderlo; este año aprendió a elaborar cócteles y cebiches; comenta que le ha ido muy bien este año en el negocio. 

Como también vende pollo y carne asada, ella viaja a la ciudad que esta aproximadamente a veinticinco kilómetros dos veces por semana a comprar los insumos para elaborar la comida; de mariscos compra alrededor de treinta librad camarón y ocho libras de pescado.

El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundación Campo, es para comprar más mariscos y preparación para el pollo y la carne azada, comprara bebida y tres juegos de mesas más. La inversión la necesita, ya que se acerca la vacación de semana santa en el país y esta temporada es muy buena para ella. Su próximo proyecto es construir una ramada de palma de coco en la playa.
texts.en:
Martha is 37 years old. She is married and has an 8-year-old daughter. Her life companion is an artisan fisherman and she is in charge of administrating the business of her mother situated at the shore of the beach, owing to the fact that her mother has diabetes and cannot continue running the business. To start, she requested her first loan to buy a kitchen and three sets of utensils. She has a year of experience and it has gone well for her. Her life companion provides her with the fish, and she is in charge of preparing and selling it. This year she learned to make cocktails and ceviches. She comments that this year in the business, it has gone well for her.  

She also sells chicken and grilled beef, so she travels to the city that is approximately 25 kilometers away, two times per week, to buy the ingredients to prepare the food. For the seafood, she buys about 30 pounds of shrimp and 8 pounds of fish.

The loan that she is requesting from Fundacion Campo is to buy more seafood and the ingredients for the chicken and grilled beef. She will buy beverages and three more sets of utensils. She needs to make the investment, given that Holy Week is getting close in the country, and this time of year is really good for her. Her next project is to build a shelter of coconut trees on the beach.

loans.use: to buy more seafood and the ingredients for chicken and grilled beef; to buy beverages and 3 more sets of utensils.

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
Loreta is 73 years old and married with six children. Loreta works very hard to provide for them.

Loreta runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell at her store.

Loreta has been in this business for 15 years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, bread, noodles and canned goods. 

In the future, Loreta would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell at her store.

loans.name: Hassanatu

texts.en:
Please meet 43-year-old Hasanatu from Sierra Leone. She is married with four children, the youngest being four years old. She also cares for two other relatives.

Hasanatu sells palm oil and works at her business eight hours a day for six days per week. She started her business because she wanted to contribute financially to her family. She was formerly a housewife. She wants to use the loan to purchase more palm oil to expand her business.  

She hopes that the extra income generated from the loan will improve the standard of education of her children. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more palm oil to expand her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy retail stock, including maize, beans, rice and cooking fat.

loans.name: Irma Esther

texts.es: Irma, tiene 28 años de edad, es casada, tiene un hijo y vive en el municipio de Azacualpa, Santa Bárbara junto a su hijo. Ella tiene su propio negocio desde hace 3 años de venta de licuados de todo tipo como ser. Licuado de banano, frutas, granola papaya, etc. Ella quiere mantener materia prima en su negocio como  ser, vasos, pajillas, leches y frutas frescas para hacer los licuados y brindar mejor servicio al cliente, para ello ha solicitado un préstamo por 7,000 Lempiras. Su plan es mantener estable su negocio y compartir junto a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Irma, 28, is married with one son and lives in the town of Azacualpa, Santa Barbara. She has been running her own business for three years, selling all kinds of smoothies such as banana, fruits, granola, papaya, etc.

She wants to maintain a good inventory of stock needed to make smoothies and provide better customer service such as cups, straws, milk and fresh fruit. Irma has requested a loan of 7,000 Lempiras. Her plan is to keep her business going and to share it with her children.

loans.use: to purchase supplies to make smoothies, such as fruit, milk, cups and straws.

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en:
This is Christina from Moriba Town in Bo, Sierra Leone.  She is 41 years old and married with five children.  Her youngest child is four years old, and currently four of her children attend school. She started her business in order to contribute financially to the home affairs, as she was previously a housewife. 

Christina has a provisions shop that sells items such as sugar, milk, sardines and biscuits.  She works eight hours per day, every day of the week. She requests this loan from BRAC Sierra Leone in order to purchase more inventory to expand her business.  

She wants to continue to see her business grow and prosper. She hopes that the loan will help improve life of her family. She thanks you in advanced for your support!

loans.use: to purchase more inventory items like soft drink, soap and sardines to expand her business.

loans.name: Haja

texts.en:
Meet 40-year-old Haja from Sierra Leone. She lives in Moriba Town in Bo, located in the southern area of the country. She is married with four children, the youngest being 3 years old. Three of her children currently go to school. Her husband is a driver. 

Haja started her business because she wanted to help support her home. She used to be a housewife. She has a business that sells local products such as fish and palm oil. She works at her business for eight hours a day, six days a week. She wants the loan to help expand and purchase more inventory including fish and palm oil. In the future, she wishes to see her business continue to expand and be more established. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory including fish and palm oil.

loans.name: Kaday

texts.en:
Please meet 45-year-old Kaday from Moriba Town, Bo in Sierra Leone. She is married with three children, all of whom attend school. Her youngest child is 11 years old. Her husband is a miner. She initially started her business in order to take part in the development of her home. 

Kaday has a business that sells palm oil and soap, and she works eight hours per day, six days per week at it. She will use the loan to purchase more palm oil and soap to expand her business. She says that the business is doing well. She hopes that the loan will help improve her family’s well-being, and she would like her business to continue to grow. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more palm oil and soap to expand her business.

loans.name: Baby

texts.en:
Please meet 44-year-old Baby from Bo, Sierra Leone, in the southern part of the country. She is married with four children, the youngest being 11 years old. All of her children are attending school. She started doing business because she wanted her own career.  

Baby has a business in Moriba Town selling dressmaking materials and fabrics such as cotton and linen. She works at her business every day for 10 hours per day. She will use the loan to purchase more materials for her business, such as cotton, linen and slippers. She would like to see her business continue to expand and grow to the next level. The extra income from her business will help her give a good education to her children. She is thankful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more materials for her business, such as cotton, linen and slippers.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
This is 25-year-old Hawa from Moriba Town, Bo. Bo is located in the southern part of Sierra Leone. She is married with two children, aged 2 and 5.  Currently, one of the children attends school. 

Hawa sells palm oil for a living. She works eight hours per day, six days per week at her business. She was a housewife but started her business to help contribute to her family. She wants to use the loan to purchase more palm oil. She wants to see her business grow larger. She wants to thank you in advance for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more palm oil.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Maa Kalijai Group

texts.en:
In the year 2012, five active women entrepreneurs of Muniguda town of Rayagada district in Odisha, India formed a group named Maa Kalijai to access a loan from Mahashakti Foundation to expand their existing business. Sasmita is one of them. The lady standing on the extreme left with a raised hand in the photograph is Sasmita. She is an energetic lady of 23 years who lives with her husband and only son, three years old 

Sasmita is has been running a silver jewelry shop in her house for the last two years. Her husband is running a utensils-selling business by moving to nearby villages and weekly markets via a moped. Previously, he was running a utensils shop in a cabin but due to lack of capital, he could not continue the same successfully. So Sasmita formed this group and took a loan of 14,000 INR from Mahashakti Foundation to invest in her business. She added another 36,000 INR from their savings and with a capital of 50,000 INR, gave a new look to the present business. They started two businesses. One is silver jewelry selling at the home for her and the other is the utensils business for her husband for mobile vending. As Sasmita had experience managing a similar type of business from her parental house, she is successfully managing her jewelery shop. Sasmita’s family earns a daily net income of 500 INR from the existing two businesses. Out of this income, she has been able to manage her household expenses in a decent manner. Sasmita buys the jewelry as well as the utensils from the local wholeseller twice a month. With the present loan, Sasmita wants to increase the stock of utensils by purchasing in bulk. This will help her to reduce the purchasing cost as she replenishes her stock frequently. Sasmita hopes to save enough money to provide better education to her only child and build a house for her own.

The other four members of the group are Anusaya, Tikina, Ramakumari and Gori who are successfully running small enterprises.

loans.use: to purchase more utensils

loans.name: Maha Laxmi Group

texts.en:
Muniguda is a small town where Radhamani, a widow age 51, is residing with her son of 31 years and a daughter of 21 years of age. Muniguda is situated in the Rayagada district of northern Odisha, India. The government has declared Rayagada as a backward district in Odisha state. Tribal people are the primitive community of this area. They depend on agro-forestry products. So some people have migrated from the coastal belt to this area to earn their livelihood by adopting some business. The family of Radhamani, the featured member standing on the extreme left with her hand raised, also migrated from another district to Muniguda and started a general grocery shop. Seven years ago, her husband, Trinath, died due to illness. She could not give him the appropriate treatment due to her poor income. After her husband’s death, she started making leaf plates and sold them in the market. Her son runs his father’s shop but their income is not sufficient to manage their family. 

Therefore, Radhamani formed a Joint liability group in the year 2010 with five women in her locality, named Maha Laxmi to get a business loan from Mahashakti Foundation. In the first loan, she got 12,000 rupees and as she has experience stitching from her parent’s house, she purchased a sewing machine. She started stitching ladies and gents dresses. In the second loan, she got an 18000/- loan from Mahashakti and purchased a Pico machine to help her in tailoring work. Her income gradually increased . In the meantime, her son married. This is the third loan for Radhamani and with this loan she is planning to purchase some new cloth to sell and stitch. Now she is very happy. She is maintaining a peaceful and pleasant life with her son, daughter and daughter in law. She has a dream of marrying her daughter to a good businessman. She is improving her business to realize her cherished dream. 

The other four members of the group are Rina, Sasmita, Subasini, and Sushama.

loans.use: to purchase clothes to sell and stitch

loans.name: Champeswar Group

texts.en:
Champeswar is a Joint Liability Group formed in the year 2009 by five active women entrepreneurs of Bhawanipatna town in Kalahandi district of Odisha, India to request a loan from Mahashakti Foundation to expand their existing businesses. Kumudini is one of them. The lady standing in the middle with her hand raised in the photograph is Kumudini. She is 38 years and lives with her husband who is working as a forest guard and three sons of 18, 14 and 12 years who are continuing their studies. 

Kumudini has been running a screen printing unit in her house for the last four years with the help of her eldest son. Prior to this, her son was working in a screen printing unit as an assistant. Her son takes orders for printing invitation cards, bill books, certificates, visiting cards etc. from customers within a radius of 20 kilometers. Her average monthly income is 8,000 INR. Her son purchases the materials like chemicals, paper, color etc from the retailers in Bhawanipatna town. Due to her quality work and timely delivery, her business has a good reputation in that locality.This is the third loan for the group from Mahashakti Foundation. With the present loan, Kumudini wants to purchase cards, color and chemicals in bulk from the wholesaler to reduce the purchasing cost as she replenishes her stock frequently. Kumudini hopes to construct a separate cabin for her business and dreams of giving a better education to her sons. 

The other four members of the group are Sumitra, Minakshi, Champa and Sanju who are running a Tiffin stall, a betel nut shop, a general grocery shop and a fruits stall, respectively.

loans.use: to purchase cards, color and chemicals in bulk .

loans.name: Adama

texts.en:
This is 33 year old Adama  from Sierra Leone.  She is married with 2 children; the youngest is 5 years old.  Her husband is a driver. 
Adama has a business that sells cosmetics in Moriba Town, Bo.  She started her business because she wanted to contribute to the home.  She works 8 hours per day, 6 days per week at her business.  She wants to use the loan to purchase more inventory including Vaseline, necklaces, hair and rings.  She says that her business is doing well and wants to continue to grow and expand it.  She is grateful for your support!

loans.use: to purchase more inventory including Vaseline, necklaces, hair and rings.

loans.name: Own

texts.en: The mother of three daughters who are factory workers, Own is 53 years old and a resident of Kandal Province, Ponhea Leur District. She is a farmer who grows rice on one hectare of land. She has been involved in this business for 32 years, and it earns her about 42,000 KHR per day. Own's past loan was her first from VisionFund, Kiva’s partner. The prior loan has supported her business and given her a good income. For this new loan cycle, she is applying for an education loan to pay for her daughter’s vocational training costs. She hopes that her daughters will own a business with stable income to support the family.

loans.use: to pay for vocational training for her daughter.

loans.name: Jean Baptiste

texts.en: Jean Baptiste is a 22-year-old man from Gakenke District in the Northern Province of Rwanda. He is seeking a loan of $50 to purchase 10 rechargeable LED lights, which he will resell to people without electricity in his village. Every week or so, these customers will return to him to have their lights recharged for just $0.20. Jean Baptiste started selling lights in October 2012 and he has sold 30 lights to date, providing clean energy to 150 people. He is also a farmer and will reinvest the money he makes into expanding his other business.

loans.use: To pay for 10 low-cost LED lights to resell to rural households without electricity.

loans.name: Setia Group

texts.en:
Feryn is 35 years old, and she describes herself as a hardworking and welcoming woman. She lives with her husband and four children in the Ciracas province of Jakarta. Her husband, Olade, works as a mechanic. Feryn started her clothing retail business on credit in her home in 2011. She sells her merchandise to her neighbors and members of her church. Sometimes she has delinquent customers but, until recently, she could handle this problem.  

Feryn will use this loan to buy house dresses, T-shirts, and children's trousers. In the future, she will expand her business to sell electronic goods. Beside produce profit to pay her children school fee, Feryn enjoy this business because she can take care of her children also.

loans.use: to buy clothes for sale.

loans.name: Abibatu

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 45-year-old Abibatu from Moriba town Bo. She is widowed with five children between the ages of 16 and 27. Three of her children are attending school. She lost her husband at an early age so to take care of the children, she went into business.

Abibatu runs a palm oil business, she sells gallons of palm oil. She has been running this business for 5 years. She works at the business 7 days per week and 10 hours per day. She says her business is doing well.

Abibatu has requested a loan in order to buy more gallons of palm oil. The extra income from this loan will allow her to improve the life of her children and give them quality education. In the future, she plans to open a big palm oil store. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy more gallons of palm oil.

loans.name: Choum

texts.en:
A 55-year-old mother of nine kids, residing in the Moung Russey district of Battambang Province, Choum is a farmer who manages two hectares of rainy season rice-growing and a three hectare area of dry season rice cropping. This primary source of income, which she has been involved with for 20 years, has returned her about 30,000 KHR per day to supply the daily food consumption for the family. 

This is not the first loan for Choum with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She is pleased with her previous loans because they have supported her business and improved her lifestyle. Now, she is seeking a new loan in order to pay a plowing fee and to buy potash. She hopes this loan will help her to grow her rice fruitfully and bring her a good yield.

loans.use: To pay a plowing fee and to buy potash.

loans.name: Peace

texts.en:
Peace is 45 years old. She sells food and has spent five years doing this. 

She is married with three children between 10 and 17, and they all attend schools. 

With the loan, she wants to buy more beans and bananas for sale. The profits from the business will be used to make more reinvestment in the same business.

loans.use: To buy more beans for sale.

loans.name: Penina

texts.en: Penina is a married woman with five children living in Bundibugyo, Uganda. Seven years ago she decided to trade in fish in order to raise school fees for her children and supplement her cocoa business which is seasonal. Price fluctuation and inadequate capital are her major hindrance to achieving her goals while her dream is to buy a refrigerated van to sell fish from. Penina intends to use the loan to buy fish and cocoa to sell.

loans.use: to buy fish and cocoa to sell.

loans.name: Sopheap's Group

texts.en:
A rural farmer from Thmor Koul district of Battambang Province, Sopheap is a 40-year-old mother of four children. Currently only two children are still students in the local state school. Therefore, Sopheap still has struggled in providing daily decent food for them through rice cropping on a two-hectare area. This is the business that she has been with for ten years. 

Sopheap has been with VisionFund for three cycles. She has fully repaid her loan, which has been injected into her current business in a gradual manner. Now, she is seeking 600,000 KHR. She leads a group of two including herself; her joint borrower is seeking 500,000 KHR. 

As the group leader, Sopheap will use her loan portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland. She highly hopes that she can gain more yield and get more income so that she can keep her children in school until tertiary level.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farmland.

loans.name: Anielyn

texts.en: Anielyn is a responsible wife who helps her husband in managing and improving their living. She has a store where she offers a variety of household necessities. She wants to improve her income to develop it a bit. But due to financial difficulties, she is now asking for a loan of Php 40,000 to  purchase toothpaste, shampoo, canned goods, sweets, noodles and candies for her business. This would be a great help to her. She really desires to make a good living. Since she was a child, she never experienced this. So now that she has her own family, she is doing her best to provide for her child.

loans.use: to  purchase toothpaste, shampoo, canned goods, sweets, noodles and candies

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en:
Innocent is 28 years old. He owns a bar and has been running this bar for three years. He is single and he says, “I am comfortable with being single.”

With the loan, Innocent wants to add more crates of beer for sale. The profits from the business will be used to build a house.

He is very thankful for the previous loan, for it helped in adding more various types of beer.

loans.use: to buy more beer for sale.

loans.name: Emmy

texts.en: Emmy is a 34 year old man with three children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He quarries stones for a living and with the proceeds he has been able to pay school fees for his children. A prolonged rainy season and lack of adequate man power pose a challenge to his business growth while his dream is to diversify the business and venture into commercialized agriculture. Emmy intends to use the loan to pay workers who are helping him in the quarry.

loans.use: to pay workers who are helping him quarry.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to build up his capital by purchasing some office supplies (copier paper, pens,...) to resell, so as to earn a living

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To rebuild his capital by buying clothing for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fish to resell

loans.name: Ibtsam

texts.en:
Ibtsam is a 28-year-old married woman. She is uneducated, living in a poor area in Haja. 

Ibstam’s house is very old and in a miserable situation. She has accumulated some money to renovate her house. It is known that house renovation takes a lot of money. 

She has started renovating her house, but now she is short of money. She needs to complete the renovation task, so she asked for a youth loan of 150,000 YER to buy construction supplies to use for completing her house. 

Ibtsam hopes that after the completion of the house renovation, she will start accumulating money to improve the life conditions of her family.

loans.use: to pay for cement and carpentry, etc. to use for completing her house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to replenish her capital by purchasing fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: replenish his capital by buying clothes for resale

loans.name: Barbienovee

texts.en:
Barbienovee, 38, has been working on her sari-sari (variety) store business for eight years. Her business is a blessing to her because it provides her income that is used for her daily expenses. She wants to continue as well as exceed the usual income to save for her future and for emergency purposes. 

Now, Barbienovee is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) to purchase additional goods such as soft drinks, a variety of canned goods, soy sauce, sugar and spices. She hopes to increase her sales through these additional products to offer.

loans.use: to purchase additional goods such as soft drinks, a variety of canned goods, soy sauce, sugar and spices.

loans.name: Ann.grameswari Self Help Group

texts.en:
Ann.Grameswari Self Help Group consists of nine members of whom all are women. These entrepreneurs are very humble, hardworking and responsible people with good manners and lots of enthusiasm to improve their lives. 

One of them is Rajani, who was selected as their president. Rajani is a 36-year-old lady living with her husband and her three children who are schooling. The lady in the third position from the left side of the photograph is Rajani. Her husband works as a laborer in a factory situated near to her village. She runs a grocery shop to help her husband financially. She sells rice, grains, lentils, edible oil, spices, biscuits, soap, detergent, hair oil etc. in her shop. She has developed a very good relationship with her customers in the village. She likes the fact that she can cater to the needs of the people in her village. 

She has a plan to make her shop bigger and keep multiple things in her shop to satisfy her customers. She also wants to purchase the items for her shop in bulk directly from the wholesalers, for which she has requested for a loan to purchase items like toothbrushes, toothpaste, soft drinks, wheat flour, grains and other household consumables.

loans.use: To purchase items like toothbrushes, toothpaste, soft drinks, wheat flour, grains and other household consumables for her grocery store.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is 53 years old and blessed with seven children. To raise them, Rosemarie engages herself in the manicure and pedicure business (on a house-to-house basis). Her experience is to walk from 9:00 o'clock in the morning to 4:00 o'clock in the afternoon around their village. She has been in this business for almost six years and earns about 350 PHP a day. 

Right now, Rosemarie is taking out this loan amounting to 7,000 PHP to buy materials needed for her business such as cotton and cuticle clippers. She hopes to have her own beauty salon someday.

loans.use: to buy materials needed for her business such as cotton and cuticle clippers

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en: Jonathan offers various kinds of vegetables inside the public market of Santiago. He is 35 years old and married with three children. Two of his children go to school while his youngest child is an infant. He dreams of being a successful entrepreneur someday, that's why he is doing his best in order to achieve his dream. One of the ways to make it possible is through borrowing additional capital. So, he is requesting a loan of PHP 20,000 which allows him to buy additional stocks of vegetables such as baguio (green) beans, broccoli, celery and red pepper for his vegetable selling business. He hopes that through this additional capital he can keep his business profitable and progressive. In this way, he can earn more income and educate his three children.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of vegetables such as baguio (green) beans, broccoli, celery and red pepper for his vegetable selling business.

loans.name: Yudi

texts.en: Yudi sells mobile phone airtime credits and also serve bill payment for the customers. Recently, he has been working in security. He has three persons living in his house. Yudi joined Ruma 11 months ago because he wanted to have additional income. He still feels really excited to expand his business of selling mobile phone airtime credits and serviing bill payments for customers. For the last 3 months, Yudi has had around $60/day in sales on average (just mobile phone airtime credit sales). As the business continues, he needs a loan for more working capital in order to be able to do transactions on weekends.

loans.use: to process more mobile phone credit sales and bill payment transactions.

loans.name: Pascasie

texts.fr:
Pascasie fait partie du groupe Dukoreneza  et est une des victimes de  l’incendie du marché central de Bujumbura. Elle est cliente de Turame depuis  2005. Elle  habite à  Bujumbura. Elle est mariée à Berchmans. Ensemble ils ont 7 enfants  âgés de  7 à  27 ans.

Elle faisait le commerce de s produits vivrier (patate douce, colocase, banane,..)au marché central de Bujumbura. Elle a perdu des marchandises d’une valeur de   5000 000FBU (3194,39 $) par l’incendie. 

Elle voudrait construire sa propre maison mais ce projet est arrêté.  

Avec le crédit KIVA qu’elle obtient, elle  va  reconstituer son capital en achetant des produits vivriers (patate douce, colocase, banane, …) à revendre pour  continuer de gagner sa vie.
texts.en:
Pascasie is part of the Dukoreneza group and is one of the victims of the fire at the central market in Bujumbura. She has been a Turame client since 2005. 

She lives in Bujumbura. She is married to Berchmans with whom she had seven children aged 7 to 27 years.

She was a vendor of food products (sweet potatoes, taro, bananas,...) at the central market in Bujumbura. She lost goods worth 5,000,000 FBU ($ 3,194.39) due to the fire.

She wants to build her own house, but that project has been stopped.

With the KIVA credit loan obtained, she will replenish her capital by buying food (sweet potatoes, taro, bananas, ...) for resale, to continue to earn a living.

loans.use: replenish her capital by buying food (sweet potatoes, taro, bananas, ...) for resale, to continue to earn a living.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy food products (palm oil, bananas, taro) to resell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: replenish her capital by buying onions for resale

loans.name: Elisabethe

texts.en:
Elisabethe is 38 years old. She is married with six children. Five of her children attend school, while the youngest child is still too young to attend school. 

She owns a hardware store where all different types of construction materials are sold. She would like to request a loan for buying more construction materials, such as cement, iron sheets, painting color and nails for resale. She plans to use the profits from this business for reinvesting in the same business.

loans.use: to buy more construction materials for resale.

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
This is Ana. She previously accessed a 20,000 PHP loan that she used to buy ingredients like flour and different spices. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would now like to apply for a 20,000 PHP loan to buy ingredients like flour, different spices and supplies. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to cover their daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Ana dreams of having her own store for her products and hopes that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for ingredients: flour, different spices and supplies needed in her business.

loans.name: Desiranta

texts.en:
Desiranta is 42 years old and lives in the town of Bombo in the Luwero region of Uganda. He is married and has six children; four of the children are currently in school. For the past 11 years, Desiranta has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells sugar, flour, rice and other items. 

To help expand his business, Desiranta has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more  commodities such as rice and sugar to sell, and will help Desiranta to generate greater profits and increase the income level of the family. Desiranta  hopes that in the future, he will be able to increase the capital. 

Desiranta  is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Desiranta who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more commodities such as rice and sugar to sell.

loans.name: Prossy's Group

texts.en:
Prossy's group is comprised of six hard-working women. Prossy is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kiyinda in Uganda. For the past two years, Prossy has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Prossy has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes to sell, and will help Prossy to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her young siblings. Prossy hopes that in the future she will be able to own another business. 

Prossy is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is 40 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married and has four children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past five years, Hassan has been working hard to manage his retail store, where he sells sugar, flour, rice, and other items. 

To help expand his business, Hassan has requested a loan of UGX 2,000,000 (Ugandan shillings) from BRAC Uganda.
